items.title: Read attributes.js info from NodeJs app
items.body:
Hi all,
Thanks for sharing this amazing library!
We need the information from the _**attributes.js**_ file (e.g. [this ](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/src/traces/scatter/attributes.js)one for the scatter trace), to use it via autocomplete in our open-source application.

Do you have any advice on how to do this?
We have tried this:
1. We do `npm install plotly.js` because the other plotly npm packages seem not to have the attributes information.
2. We then call `require("C:\Users\admin\.node-red\node_modules\plotly.js\src\traces\scatter\attributes.js");` as a simple test.
3. But then we get _**Uncaught ReferenceError: window is not defined**_ because we are in NodeJs (instead of in a browser):

   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14224149/90604067-92da2700-e1fc-11ea-8343-52f707333254.png)

Does anybody knows a better way to achieve this?
Thanks a lot !!
Bart

items.title: Clean unneeded and deprecated dependencies
items.body:
Due to some packages such as regl/splom, plotly.js makes us download/use uneeded and deprecated dependencies such as `left-pad` while they are not even needed. (See https://github.com/gl-vis/regl-splom/pull/18)

When installing through npm I get the following warnings:


> npm WARN deprecated os-homedir@2.0.0: This is not needed anymore. Use `require('os').homedir()` instead.
> npm WARN deprecated left-pad@1.3.0: use String.prototype.padStart()

I think it would do good to the project to clean such dependencies.

items.title: Encountered two full labels using ticklabelmode: 'period'
items.body: [testing this out](https://codepen.io/alexcjohnson/pen/dyMYeXy?editors=1010) this seems to introduce a (much more minor) bug with regular non-reversed axes when the tick corresponding to the first ~tick~ label is just out-of-range, we get the full 2-line label twice: It'd be nice to include jasmine tests for ^^ both forward and reversed, with the original range shifted in something like 6-hour increments - so ranges: ``` ['2019-12-29', '2020-01-04'] ['2019-12-29 06', '2020-01-04 06'] ['2019-12-29 12', '2020-01-04 12'] ['2019-12-29 18', '2020-01-04 18'] ['2020-01-04 18', '2019-12-29 18'] ['2020-01-04 12', '2019-12-29 12'] ['2020-01-04 06', '2019-12-29 06'] ['2020-01-04', '2019-12-29'] ``` And just check that the tick text we get in each case is as expected. Something like that should cover all the related cases, I'd think. _Originally posted by @alexcjohnson in https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/pull/5060#issuecomment-672307059_

items.title: Base attribute bug
items.body:
I have tried to make simple timeline with the help of base attribute. Run into problem with low x values. If x is lower than 10000 ms, plot breaks as seen in example. With values higher than 10s, plot works as expected.  Possible bug, thanks for help or maybe explanation if i am doing something wrong. 

Codepen - https://codepen.io/kristi-n-krob-nek/pen/dyMoKNJ

Also tried to look for similar issue before posting, but found nothing close to this problem.

items.title: X Axis labels disappear starting in version 1.54.6
items.body:
First off I would like to apologize for not having example code to share. I just wanted to make a note so the information and testing I have done is not lost. 
We started using plotly.js with an Angular 9 project recently and discovered that when zooming in/out, auto scaling, and resetting axes the X labels would disappear. The project uses angular-plotly.js": "2.0.0" to create components out of the graphs. 
We started with the latest version of plotly: "plotly.js": "1.54.7" and saw the issue appear. I then moved the version to 1.53.0 and the problem disappeared. I then slowly moved up the versions until it reappeared at version 1.54.6. 
Version 1.54.5 seems to work correctly so there is something between 1.54.5 and 1.54.6 that is causing the issue. 
I attempted to download plots as a png but the x axis appears to be intact rendering them useless for the purpose of demonstration.

items.title: The wheel scroll for tables doesn't work with firefox.
items.body:
Scrollable tables can't be scrolled by using the wheel on firefox because they use the 'wheelscroll' event which is not supported by this browser. 
I submitted a PR with a fix proposal:
#5051

items.title: displayModeBar does not recognize false in quotes as a valid value
items.body:
Hi,

we have the following issue (LayTec-AG/Plotly.Blazor#34) while using JavaScript-Interop in Plotly.Blazor.

"True" is recognized as a valid value in quotation marks, "False" is not.


Works:
`Plotly.newPlot('myDiv', data, layout, {displayModeBar: "hover"})` --> in quotes
`Plotly.newPlot('myDiv', data, layout, {displayModeBar: "true"})` --> in quotes
`Plotly.newPlot('myDiv', data, layout, {displayModeBar: true})` --> not in quotes
`Plotly.newPlot('myDiv', data, layout, {displayModeBar: false})` --> not in quotes

Does not work:
`Plotly.newPlot('myDiv', data, layout, {displayModeBar: "false"})`  --> in quotes


You can try it [here](https://codepen.io/seanmcl/pen/eYZYVNv).


Would that be easy for you to fix? Otherwise I would have to think of a converter that can serialize enums as booleans, which would be a nasty fix.

Have a nice week!

With kind regards

Sean

items.title: Custom Partial Bundle - Scatter3d - Not working.
items.body: I'm trying to load my own custom partial bundle, because I only need the Scatter3d. I was not successful. There might be a bug which might be related to issue: -https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/4883 Here's the code sandbox link and screenshot. - https://codesandbox.io/s/proud-dawn-i907r?file=/src/App.js:183-206 I found these related issues to help me with this - https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/4883 (no calendar on partial bundles) - https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/4891 (How to reduce bundle size of Plotly.js for 3D surface chart?) # Here's the sandbox of my actual project which is working fine currently because i'm using the plotly partial bundle (OK) - https://codesandbox.io/s/nervous-water-7rwhh?file=/src/components/HexapodPlot.js # Here's the sandbox where I'm using a custom partial bundle (NOT OK) - https://codesandbox.io/s/patient-rgb-knowb?file=/src/components/CustomPlot.js # This is the only difference between the two: - https://github.com/mithi/hexapod/blob/custom-plotly-bundle-error/src/components/CustomPlot.js - https://github.com/mithi/hexapod/blob/custom-plotly-bundle-error/src/components/HexapodPlot.js ```js import Plotly from "plotly.js/lib/core"; import Scatter3d from "plotly.js/lib/scatter3d" import createPlotlyComponent from "react-plotly.js/factory"; Plotly.register([Scatter3d]); const CustomPlotly = createPlotlyComponent(Plotly); export default CustomPlotly; ``` # Console log errors when running on local ``` react_devtools_backend.js:2273 WARN: webgl setup failed possibly due to enabling preserveDrawingBuffer config. The device may not be supported by is-mobile module! Inverting preserveDrawingBuffer option in second attempt to create webgl scene. ``` On Chrome `Version 84.0.4147.89 (Official Build) (64-bit)`, MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Mid 2014) MacOs Catalina 10.15.5 Also happens on firefox 78.0.2 (64-bit) # Additional info # 1 I experimented with https://github.com/mithi/plotly-webpack and was somewhat successful (I wasn't able to load the paper background)... I found out that I can reproduce my plot having only a gzipped bundle size of `~410kb`. This is significantly lower than when I use `plotly.js-gl3d-dist-min` - The latter has a gzipped bundle size of `~450kb` # Additional info # 2 Importing all the requirements here https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/lib/index-gl3d.js ``` require('./scatter3d'), require('./surface'), require('./mesh3d'), require('./isosurface'), require('./volume'), require('./cone'), require('./streamtube') ``` produces the same error discussed above ... while Commenting out `Plotly.register([Scatter3d]);` Will remove the error and produce the following I also saw this issue which might be related https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/4989 But i don't know how to fix it in my case. Any help is appreciated! Thanks!

items.title: Custom tick labels drawn on wrong axis in subplot
items.body:
When using a second set of x and y axis in a subplot, custom tick labels are drawn on the wrong axis. 
This only occurs when: 
- Subplots are on two rows (works for columns)
- Custom tick labels using `tickvals` and `ticktext`
- The labels should be drawn on x axis (works for y axis)

Reproducible example: https://codepen.io/cest-m/pen/OJMEbwZ
Version used: latest un-minified

![wrongAxisLabel](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68110658/87276163-0e4f0700-c4e0-11ea-87a0-0696b7233b36.png)

items.title: webgl not supported
items.body:
WARN: webgl setup failed possibly due to enabling preserveDrawingBuffer config. The device may not be supported by is-mobile module! Inverting preserveDrawingBuffer option in second attempt to create webgl scene.

The above message is displayed despite that my browser supports WebGL as [here](https://get.webgl.org/)

The environment:
Angular: 9.0.7
PlotlyJS: 1.54.5
Chrome: Version 83.0.4103.116 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Steps to reproduce:
1. create an angular 9 project
2. npm install plotly.js
3. add plotly.min.js in scripts in angular.json:
           `"scripts": [
              "node_modules/plotly.js/dist/plotly.min.js"
            ]`
4. create an angular component and add a [3D surface plot](https://plotly.com/javascript/3d-surface-plots/#surface-plot-with-contours) from docs
5. ng serve --prod

When using the --prod from angular compiler, I think that the already minified plotly.min.js gets bundled and minified in a wrong way. If the angular app is served or build without the '--prod' option everything works as expected.

PS: The last version of Plotly that is still working with --prod flag is 1.41.3

SS without --prod
![plotly2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14039720/86948531-ef561b00-c155-11ea-9141-2aeb0506ed7a.png)

SS with --prod
![plotly1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14039720/86948529-eebd8480-c155-11ea-8c5f-4d9a336f4eb9.png)
![plotly3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14039720/86948532-efeeb180-c155-11ea-9610-cb2de8346b17.png)

items.body:
There is something buggy going on with my subplots using x unified

When creating the plot on its own, the hoverlabel is fine, but when I put it inside a dash app via dcc.Graph component, the labels don’t show. I created two versions in chart studio, one that is exported from the dash app and the second created using the `chart_studio` module.

The latter works fine, but the former works initially, but then all but the last plot’s hover labels no longer work when the window is resized.

Any idea what is going on here?

Created using chart_studio (works good): https://chart-studio.plotly.com/~mbkupfer/70/#plot

Dependencies:

```
dash                      1.13.3
dash-core-components      1.10.1
dash-html-components      1.0.3
dash-renderer             1.5.0
dash-table                4.8.1
plotly                    4.8.2
```
**[Update]**
It actually looks like this issue occurs in both created plots.

items.title: heatmapgl does not coerce its own attributes
items.body:
The `heatmapgl` trace needs its own `default` function.
Right now it uses `heatmap` default and attributes.
As a result attributes e.g. `zsmooth`, `xgap`, `connectgaps`, `hoverongaps`, and more get into `gd._fullData`.

items.title: Triangle markers that end on points rather than center on them
items.body:
In order to make an "arrow chart" out of a scatter trace, we need to be able to have arrowhead/triangle markers whose extreme end is at the point, rather than markers centered on a point: right now if I want an arrow from 10 to 20, the tip of the triangle overshoots.

I propose we add four new markers `arrowhead-*` for this purpose.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/203523/85309468-a37e5300-b480-11ea-8f97-09369b9db3a7.png)

items.title: Misalignment of candlestick, ohlc and box plots when using rangebreaks
items.body:
Hi,

The candlesticks in my plot are not aligned (the sticks are misaligned with the candle) when I use the rangebreak option when generating the plot.

Here's a sample: https://codepen.io/pkmar78/pen/oNbZwmQ

This issue does not occur for all charts, the above is just one example of where it occurred when I was testing this. I also looked at previous issues when rangebreak where just sticks were displayed instead of candlesticks (#4742) but I'm not sure if this is also a similar bug.

This issue does not occur if I remove the rangebreak settings from the plot parameters. 

Here's a pic of the misalignment:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5354407/85226040-e85ba880-b3f2-11ea-9a3f-df1212070285.png)

Could this be due to non-uniform dates? or is there any other param that I should be using, but missing from my code?

Plotly version used: 1.54.3
Source: https://cdn.plot.ly/plotly-1.54.3.min.js

items.title: Integrating discrete-heatmap2d
items.body: @ordiology has [patched `gl-heatmap2d`](https://github.com/gl-vis/gl-heatmap2d/compare/master...ordiology:discrete-heatmap2d) to implementing discretization, which could be used to resolve https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/2924 by implementing `zsmooth` on `heatmapgl` (i.e. enabling it to be set to `false`)... Let's help them prepare a PR to get this functionality exposed in Plotly.js.

items.title: Documentation incorrectly states tickmode *must* be "array" for tickvals/ticktext to work
items.body:
The [documentation for ticktext and tickvals](https://plotly.com/javascript/reference/#layout-xaxis-tickvals) states that "Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to "array"." 

The **opposite** of this is true, if the X axis is datetime type (or detected to be such). In this case, by adding `tickmode: "array"` to the `xaxis` options, the `ticktext` and `tickmode` values are totally ignored. Removing the `tickmode` setting produces the desired behaviour but is completely counter to what the documentation says. 

Here is an example **without** `tickmode` being set, and the X axis tick labels are as wanted, adding in `tickmode: "array"` to the xaxis options will cause it to revert to automatic date labels: https://codepen.io/etpinard/pen/YWEdJX

Fixing the code would be best (although will create breaking changes for users of this quirk) but fixing the documentation would be a good start...

items.title: ids for heatmap, contour, surface, do not work in animation
items.body:
Each trace type has the attribute `ids` which is described invariably as:
 ```
ids
Type: list, numpy array, or Pandas series of numbers, strings, or datetimes.
Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.
```
I realized that I haven't seen during the last 4 years of   Plotly animation any example involving  `ids`. and tried to understand their role in animation.

It makes sense to associate ids  for `Scatter`plots, mode='markers' or `Bar`, because we can assign an id to each marker, respectively bar, and generate animations like shuffling markers in a scatter plot or define a bar chart race, which is a very popular animation, but I'm wondering what is the connection between heatmap `ids`, and its data.  I tried to assign an id to each element, `z[i][j]`,  of the array, `z`,  that defines a heatmap. Namely I defined a heatmap animation
with `fig.data[0]`  defined simply by:
```
go.Heatmap(z=z_init, colorscale='matter' , ids = ids)
```
where `ids` was   either as an array of strings of the same shape like `z_init` or an array resulted by flattening the former one.

I defined each frame such that its `data[0]` updates only `ids`  by shuffling the elements of the initial array of `ids`.  No one worked, while with the same frame definition for a scatter plot, the markers have been shuffled.

The same question can be addressed for Contour, Surface,  etc: what data were envisioned to have an id?

items.title: Parcoords - lines disappear, categorical axis with single tick
items.body:
In parcoords, unexpected behavior happens when applying brush to a categorical dimension with single tickval and ticktext. When brush is applied to this dimension (to the single tick,  then applied brush has no meaning), all lines disappear. After clicking on the (hidden) dimension and removing brush, lines appear again.

Also, I noticed when there are applied brushes to other dimensions (so far the chart behaves properly), it is impossible to apply the brush to this single tickval / ticktext dimension .

See below:

https://codepen.io/martin-hejtm-nek/pen/mdeYGYv

items.title: Interactive bar chart doesn't show all the bars.
items.body:
Hi,

I have the following dataframe and I am trying to create an interactive bar chart with plotly.express:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

    import pandas as pd
    import plotly.express as px
    
    data = {
            'Profile': ['PK', 'OP', 'PK', 'OP', 'PK', 'OP', 'PK', 'OP'],
            'Date': ['2020-01-01', '2020-01-01', '2020-01-02', '2020-01-02', '2020-01-01', '2020-01-01', '2020-01-02', '2020-01-02'],
            'Month': ['Jan-20','Jan-20','Jan-20','Jan-20','Feb-20','Feb-20','Feb-20','Feb-20'],
            'Value': [10, 20, 60, 70, 30, 60, 55,89]
        }
    
    df = pd.DataFrame(data=data, columns=['Profile','Date', 'Month', 'Value'])
    
    fig = px.bar(data_frame=df, x='Month', y='Value', animation_frame='Date', animation_group='Profile')

    fig.show()

Even though the chart appears, only the first bar has color, the rest are transparent.

[![enter image description here][2]][2]

Plotly version is 4.7.1

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/bWGm4.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/zl4kB.png

items.title: Explicitly setting tickmode to array disables tickvals in date axis

items.body: Currently, a few specific versions are used (here's an example: https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/commit/ecff28e5c465a08b08d8eb001bb50e3cdb8f4a0a ), but this can cause multiple versions to be installed by users, so could `^` or `~` be sure to allow more flexibility in what's installed?

items.title: Shapes on below layer hides hover labels on 1.54.0
(x|y)axis.hovertemplate
items.body:
Today with hovermode='x' or 'x unified' the x-value is shown either in its own little axis-attached hoverlabel, or at the top of the unified hoverlabel, but there is no way to control its formatting:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/203523/80804144-494cca00-8b82-11ea-8563-e768cbcf0112.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/203523/80804163-59fd4000-8b82-11ea-8332-c94c3d9650f0.png)

This is especially problematic for date axes, where people might have strong opinions about how dates should be formatted.

The proposed solution is to add `layout.xaxis.hovertemplate` which could be set to something like `%{x:<d3 number format>}` or `%{x|<d3 date format}` or even something more fanciful like `The date here is %{x}.` etc. We would implement the same thing for the y axis when hovermode is 'y' or 'y unified', naturally.

items.title: Getting error "Cannot read property 'document' of undefined" in console while using plotly JS, type: Indicator(shape: bullet)
items.body:
Thanks for your interest in plotly.js!

Before opening an issue, please search for existing and closed issues. If your problem or idea is not addressed yet, [please open a new issue](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/new).

Bug reports **must** be accompanied with a reproducible example. We recommend using [codepen](http://codepen.io/), [jsfiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/) or [jsbin](https://jsbin.com) to share your example. Please use the [latest un-minified version](https://cdn.plot.ly/plotly-latest.js) of plotly.js in your report unless not applicable.

If you don't know JavaScript and still want to help us by reporting a bug, please attach the `"data"` and `"layout"` attributes that describe your graph and updates (if required to detect the bug). One way to retrieve your graph's data and layout attributes is by exporting your graph to [Plotly Cloud](http://plot.ly/). To do so, click on the _Edit in Chart Studio_ mode bar button (the 2nd one from the left by default) and follow these [instructions](https://help.plot.ly/save-share-and-export-in-plotly/), or watch this [screencast](https://community.plot.ly/t/mega-sharing-graphs-with-chart-studio/8869).

Issues found on the example pages from https://plot.ly/javascript/ should be filed in our [documentation repo](https://github.com/plotly/documentation/issues) with the exception of https://plot.ly/javascript/reference which should be filed here.

Note that GitHub issues are reserved for bug reports and feature requests only. Implementation questions should be asked on community.plot.ly (tagged [`plotly-js`](http://community.plot.ly/c/plotly-js)) or on Stack Overflow (tagged [`plotly`](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/plotly)).

Comments on GitHub issues or pull requests should add content to the discussions. Approbation comments such as *+1* or *I would like this feature to be implemented as well* will be deleted by the maintainers. Please use [GitHub reactions](https://github.com/blog/2119-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments) instead.

items.title: Using hour rangebreaks causes candlestick chart to fail
items.body:
Using an hour rangebreak, in my case `{'pattern': 'hour', 'bounds': [16, 9.5]}` (2nd last line) causes the candlestick chart to not plot open/close boxes and it breaks the hovering feature to preview data. There is also more space between points but I assumed that was because the lack of candle boxes.

Data:
[data.xlsx](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.py/files/4536643/data.xlsx)

Code:
`import pandas as pd
from plotly.offline import plot
import plotly.graph_objects as go
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots

df = pd.read_excel('data.xlsx')

#Plot Chart
fig = make_subplots(          
    rows=2, cols=1, 
    subplot_titles=('Price', 'Volume'),
    shared_xaxes=True,
    vertical_spacing=0.3)
fig.add_trace(go.Candlestick( #Candlesticks
    x=df['date'], open=df['open'], high=df['high'], low=df['low'], close=df['close']),
    row=1, col=1)
fig.add_trace(go.Bar( #Volume
    x=df['date'], y=df['volume'],
    marker_color='blue'),
    row=2, col=1,)
fig.update_layout(
    title_text='AAPL Technical Analysis',
    xaxis_rangeslider_visible=True,
    showlegend=False)
fig.update_xaxes(
    rangebreaks=[
        {'pattern': 'day of week', 'bounds': [6, 1]}, #Break weekends
        {'pattern': 'hour', 'bounds': [16, 9.5]}]) #Break after hours and market close

plot(fig)`

Remove `{'pattern': 'hour', 'bounds': [16, 9.5]}` to see correct candlesticks but I don't want to plot times where the market is after hours or closed.

Python 3.7.7, all modules are updated

Thanks

The issue with the bar grouping value is here: https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/4749

items.title: [Bug] data[type=scattergl ]  gives error if webGL is not supported
items.body:
When browser does not have webGL enabled, ```type=scattergl``` gives error on console.
See error below
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4101480/79355979-d0315e00-7f57-11ea-9cca-331428e06d48.png)


**Steps To Reproduce:**
I used firefox => ```about:config ```  =>  ```webgl.disabled: true  ``` to disable webGL to reproduce this issue.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4101480/79356266-2acaba00-7f58-11ea-9237-bdeffb295908.png)


**Expected Behaviour:** 
Instead of error , plotly should display following message just like ```type=scatter3d``` or ```type=isosurface```

> WebGL is not supported by your browser - visit https://get.webgl.org for more info

(disable webGL first) (Correct Behaviour scatter3d)
 https://codepen.io/mafar/pen/ZEbQLZm?editors=1010


**Incorrect Behaviour: scattergl**
(disable webGL first)
https://codepen.io/mafar/pen/XWmXpoO?editors=1010


**Comparison:**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4101480/79357864-fe17a200-7f59-11ea-8654-374f775d1e66.png)

items.title: Mock bar_multiline_labels has unexpected layout  "legend" value "none"
items.body:
My Scala scanner/parser failed on the [bar_multiline_labels.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/bar_multiline_labels.json). The "legend" attribute in the following [snippet](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/bar_multiline_labels.json#L157) (removed the other axis) is the _culprit_: 

```json
    "layout":{
        "showlegend": false,
        "xaxis": {
            "ticks": "outside",
            "domain": [0, 0.4]
        },
        "legend": "none",
        "height":800,
        "width":800
    }
```
According to the schema, it seems that the value should always be a JSON object. I am also assuming that `"none"` may have been used to remove/hide the legend but now we have a `"showlegend"` (set to false above).

Is this an error? Does removing the `"lengend"` correct this issue? If so, should I make PR with this element removed? 

TIA

items.title: Candlestick body width bug with range breaks
items.body:
Hello everyone,

I am using plotly with python and found a bug with the new (very useful) rangebreaks feature.

When using candlestick graphs it generates some kind of *yaxis size reduction* on the body of every candles, resulting in what look likes **vertical lines** for **each candles**.

I created a codepen with and without rangebreaks as the only difference.

Thanks a lot for this great library,

[codepen link](https://codepen.io/matdecac/pen/JjYPwRv)

Mathias

items.title: `restyle` and `update` functions do not work for choroplethmapbox
items.body:
`restyle` and `update` functions do not work for `choroplethmapbox`. Only `relayout` is working.
This issue was mentioned on Plotly forum here [https://community.plotly.com/t/menu-or-button-to-change-the-value-on-a-map-choroplethmapbox/32819](https://community.plotly.com/t/menu-or-button-to-change-the-value-on-a-map-choroplethmapbox/32819).
In an attempt to answer this question [https://community.plotly.com/t/drop-down-menu-change-color-choropleth-map/37247](https://community.plotly.com/t/drop-down-menu-change-color-choropleth-map/37247) I created an example, and I can confirm  that only `relayout` works for choroplethmapbox.  I can post the Python code if it is required.
For `restyle` I defined another z-data while for `update` both z-data and "coloraxis.colorscale"

items.title: The opacityscale, 'extremes', has constant opacity equal to 1
items.body:
The function `createWave()` [https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/d37895bd64227433229f2b3f91c9e14fd6ec7b89/src/traces/surface/defaults.js#L19](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/d37895bd64227433229f2b3f91c9e14fd6ec7b89/src/traces/surface/defaults.js#L19) generates an opacityscale with all opacities equal to 1, because:
```
 Math.max(1, Math.min(0, v)) // line 27
```
is 1 for any v.

Replacing it by:
```
 Math.min(1, Math.max(0, v)) 
```
removes the actual drawback, and leads to a non-constant opacityscale.

items.title: JSON Mock with numeric Funnel.line.dash value
items.body:
I have the mock [funnel_vertical_overlay_custom_arrays.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/funnel_vertical_overlay_custom_arrays.json) that  sets the line `dash` to `10`. Would I be correct in assuming that a value of `"10"` is ok (i.e: changing the mock value to string is correct)? For the values `0` to `5` I assume `0` refers to `"solid"`, no? If so I guess the value `10` is incorrect?

Looking at the schema below it seems like this is a candidate for "enumerate".  This would allow the Scala API to set the correct value. I see that issue https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/2903 has already referred to this possibility. Would it make sense for me to make a request?

TIA.

```json
                "connector": {
                    "line": {
                        "color": {
                            "valType": "color",
                            "role": "style",
                            "editType": "style",
                            "description": "Sets the line color.",
                            "dflt": "#444"
                        },
                        "width": {
                            "valType": "number",
                            "min": 0,
                            "dflt": 2,
                            "role": "style",
                            "editType": "plot",
                            "description": "Sets the line width (in px)."
                        },
                        "dash": {
                            "valType": "string",
                            "values": [
                                "solid",
                                "dot",
                                "dash",
                                "longdash",
                                "dashdot",
                                "longdashdot"
                            ],
                            "dflt": "solid",
                            "role": "style",
                            "editType": "style",
                            "description": "Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*)."
                        },
                        "editType": "plot",
                        "role": "object"
                    },
```


items.title: How best to interpret/parse "items"  with no "role" or "valType"
items.body:
I realize this may not be the best place to ask this. If so please redirect me to a more appropriate forum.  

My testing of a Scala wrapper failed on (among others) these mocks:

*  [gl2d_parcoords_select_first_last_enum.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/gl2d_parcoords_select_first_last_enum.json)
* [cheater_constraint_greater_than_with_hill.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/cheater_constraint_greater_than_with_hill.json)
* [mocks/box-violin-x0-category-position.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/box-violin-x0-category-position.json)
* [indicator_format_extremes.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/indicator_format_extremes.json)
* [splom_lower-nodiag-matching.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/splom_lower-nodiag-matching.json)
* [bar-alignment-offset.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/bar-alignment-offset.json)
* [cheater_constraint_outer_range_hi_top.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/cheater_constraint_outer_range_hi_top.json)
* [fonts.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/fonts.json)

I have realized that all have a schema with the following _shape_ (example based on `gl2d_parcoords_select_first_last_enum.json`):

```json
                "dimensions": {
                    "items": {
                        "dimension": {
                            "label": {
                                "valType": "string",
                                "role": "info",
                                "editType": "plot",
                                "description": "The shown name of the dimension."
                            },
                            "tickvals": {
                                "valType": "data_array",
                                "editType": "plot",
                                "description": "Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear.",
                                "role": "data"
                            },
                           "role": "object"
                    },
                    "role": "object"
                },
```

Looking at the JSON documents, it seems like `"items"` is a JSON array that contains objects of a specific _type_ (in the example above it would be  `"dimension"`). But the schema does not seem to make this explicit. Trying to work out how to parse this consistently. How should I go about it - can I assume that this is always so?

I may be missing something, but this may be a candidate for another `"valOjects"`. By tagging `"items"`it would make it easier to parse. 

Appreciate any help.

items.title: Test mock with numeric  "offsetgroup" value
items.body:
The mock [bar-alignment-offset.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/bar-alignment-offset.json) has the following trace: 

```json
    {
      "type": "bar",
      "marker": {
        "color": "orange"
      },
      "opacity": 0.6,
      "name": "B",
      "legendgroup": "B",
      "showlegend": false,
      "hoverinfo": "text",
      "hovertext": "a0",
      "xaxis": "x",
      "yaxis": "y",
      "alignmentgroup": "a",
      "offsetgroup": 0,
      "x": [
        1
      ],
      "y": [
        1
      ]
    },
```

Note that the `"offsetgroup"` has a numeric value. But the schema indicates:

```
valType : "string"
```
The few examples I have found in Plotly's Github and project/product sites seem to use strings.  Is the mock incorrect?

TIA

items.title: Test mock with unexpected "barnorm" value
items.body:
The mock [bar_attrs_overlay.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/bar_attrs_overlay.json) has the following layout:
```json
    "layout":{
        "xaxis": {"showgrid":true},
        "height":400,
        "width":400,
        "barmode":"overlay",
        "barnorm":false
    }
```

Testing based on the schema resulted in a parsing error of  `"barnorm"`. The schema has: 

```json
"barnorm": {
                    "valType": "enumerated",
                    "values": [
                        "",
                        "fraction",
                        "percent"
                    ],
                    "dflt": "",
                    "role": "info",
                    "editType": "calc",
                    "description": "Sets the normalization for bar traces on the graph. With *fraction*, the value of each bar is divided by the sum of all values at that location coordinate. *percent* is the same but multiplied by 100 to show percentages."
                },
```
Is that an error or can we have false values?

TIA

items.title: Test mock with no trace "type"
items.body:
I am trying to test a Scala wrapper on the Plotly.JS tests. I have found that some mocks do not have the trace `type`. One example is [overlaying-axis-lines.json](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/test/image/mocks/overlaying-axis-lines.json).

Is this intended? Does this imply a default trace type (these mocks do have a base plot)? I tried to find this in the documentation but did not succeed. 

TIA

But everything else is great, and even this one is more correct than before, just uglier. It's an obscure enough edge case that I'd be happy merging and releasing like this, and flagging this for follow-up later. _Originally posted by @alexcjohnson in https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/pull/4696#issuecomment-605214827_

items.title: hoverlabel formatting in unified mode
items.body:
The intention for unified hoverlabel formatting is that if `layout.hoverlabel` isn't specified, it will use the settings from `layout.legend` for e.g. `bgcolor` and `font` etc, otherwise it will use the `layout.hoverlabel` settings.

Right now it seems like neither work to override the hoverlabel formatting in `x unified` mode

items.title: orthographic
items.body:
Thanks for your interest in plotly.js!

Before opening an issue, please search for existing and closed issues. If your problem or idea is not addressed yet, [please open a new issue](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/issues/new).

Bug reports **must** be accompanied with a reproducible example. We recommend using [codepen](http://codepen.io/), [jsfiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/) or [jsbin](https://jsbin.com) to share your example. Please use the [latest un-minified version](https://cdn.plot.ly/plotly-latest.js) of plotly.js in your report unless not applicable.

If you don't know JavaScript and still want to help us by reporting a bug, please attach the `"data"` and `"layout"` attributes that describe your graph and updates (if required to detect the bug). One way to retrieve your graph's data and layout attributes is by exporting your graph to [Plotly Cloud](http://plot.ly/). To do so, click on the _Edit in Chart Studio_ mode bar button (the 2nd one from the left by default) and follow these [instructions](https://help.plot.ly/save-share-and-export-in-plotly/), or watch this [screencast](https://community.plot.ly/t/mega-sharing-graphs-with-chart-studio/8869).

Issues found on the example pages from https://plot.ly/javascript/ should be filed in our [documentation repo](https://github.com/plotly/documentation/issues) with the exception of https://plot.ly/javascript/reference which should be filed here.

Note that GitHub issues are reserved for bug reports and feature requests only. Implementation questions should be asked on community.plot.ly (tagged [`plotly-js`](http://community.plot.ly/c/plotly-js)) or on Stack Overflow (tagged [`plotly`](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/plotly)).

Comments on GitHub issues or pull requests should add content to the discussions. Approbation comments such as *+1* or *I would like this feature to be implemented as well* will be deleted by the maintainers. Please use [GitHub reactions](https://github.com/blog/2119-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments) instead.

items.title: unable to set tick0, dtick, tickvals, tickmode via template
items.body: Unable to set `tick0`, `dtick`, `tickvals`, `tickmode` via `template`.

items.title: unable to set various layout components via template
items.body:
The following components appear not be accessible via `template`.
`annotations`
`annotations3d`
`grid`
`images`
`rangeselector`
`shapes`
`sliders`
`updatemenus`
`buttons`
`mapbox.layers`

items.title: New rangebreaks and unified hover should work from templates
items.body:
I should be able to set `rangebreaks` and `hovermode="x unified"` inside `layout.template.layout` instead of `layout` and have things work identically.

As an aside: this is an invariant which should be the case for all attributes! I just QA'ed these two by chance but we should probably look into previous recently-added attributes to ensure that they work.

items.title: gridlines, ticks and ticklabels within rangebreaks
items.body:
If one or more gridlines/ticks/ticklabels would have been drawn within a rangebreak, we should draw the first one at the break.

Possibly involves https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/pull/4614/files#diff-f6d5ed25a5d6f57c70063e1e1bbc407dR616

items.title: spike/hover congruence
items.body:
It should be possible to configure things (and in unified hover mode this should be the default coerced configuration) such that whenever a hoverlabel appears, a spikeline appears and vice-versa: you should not see a spikeline without a hoverlabel.

This should hold true for mixes of bars and scatters, and work with #4656

items.title: compare/unified hover should include all points at same coordinate
items.body:
In x-unified and x-compare modes, it should never be possible for there to be two data with the same x-coordinate and only one of them is displayed in a hoverlabel. I know compare mode doesn't currently behave this way but I consider it a bug.

The solution proposed by @alexcjohnson seems good to me:

* Step 1: find hover points the way we do now
* Step 2: loop back over traces not in the set of hover points we already found, and see if any of them have a point with position-axis value exactly matching what we found for the other point(s)

items.title: Range break semantics
items.body:
Per Slack, we want to have three modes of operation, after #4653 is merged:

* pattern="day of week"/bounds: in this mode, we accept only integer values in bounds, and operation is always `[]`
* pattern="hour"/bounds/operation: in this mode we accept floats in bounds and operation is honoured for points at the boundaries
* values/operation: in this mode we accept ISO datetime values and operation is honoured for points at the boundaries

items.title: Updatemenus: traces of the same type are similarly updated, despite settings
items.body:
Defined    subplots with two heatmaps and a bar chart. In an attempt to  use a dropdown menu
to update only the second heatmap, by  setting  `traces =[1]` in button's `args` definition,  it  can be noticed that the first heatmap is also updated, with the same data like the second one, i.e. after each update both heatmaps exhibit identical patterns.

Examples to reproduce this bug: [https://chart-studio.plot.ly/~empet/15569](https://chart-studio.plot.ly/~empet/15569)

items.title: stacked histograms have different start/end values on hover
items.body:
https://codepen.io/nicolaskruchten/pen/BaNxYzM

This is weird:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/203523/76764985-1c785b00-676c-11ea-8601-542a62927cb2.png)

items.title: Allow custom sizes for treemap nodes
items.body: This would be useful for quickly visualizing the relative weight of nodes.

items.title: Bars with NaNs as positions lead to console errors
items.body:
Go to https://codepen.io/etpinard/pen/YzXeooZ?editors=0010 open the console, you should see:

```
Error: <path> attribute d: Expected number, "MNaN,620V620HNaNV…".
```

As detected in https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/pull/4614#issuecomment-597253006 (but this happens w/o setting axis breaks!)

----

From @archmoj https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/pull/4614#issuecomment-597263534 :

Something went wrong in [v1.50.0](https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/releases/tag/v1.50.0) | [demo-console-error](https://codepen.io/MojtabaSamimi/pen/abOEerE?editors=1000).
Possibly a side effect of `Add transition support to bar trace length, width, on-graph text positioning,
marker style and error bars` [#4180, #4186]

https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/pull/4614#issuecomment-597266796 - It could be related to 

![Screenshot from 2020-03-10 15-18-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33888540/76350621-7ac3ba80-62e2-11ea-893e-ac90e9fa8399.png)

in https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/pull/4180/commits/f49828a05fdf593097083842b31cbc2f8f777c11

items.title: spike lines do not appear when `spikedistance`
items.body:
At least in some traces: https://codepen.io/antoinerg/pen/BaNYJve

To be clear, this test will fail: https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/commit/9d1325c75c1526caf174f0c4c93504c8c71c8e81

Affects traces:
- bar
- ohlc

items.title: Possible value error in schema for a `dflt` field in the `indicator` trace
items.body:
I am developing Scala code to automatically generate a Scala API based in the schema (akin to Python). Got nearly all schema coded. However the following element:
```
value<-threshold<-gauge<-attributes<-indicator<-traces<-schema<-*
```
has:

```
valtype: "number"
dflt: false
```

Am I correct in assuming that the `dflt` value should only be numeric? 

TIA
